A '''lockout''' is a [[work stoppage]] in which an [[employer]] prevents employees from working. This is different from a [[strike action|strike]], in which employees refuse to work.
== Causes ==
A lockout may happen for several reasons. One reason is so that employers can lower its costs by using a lockout to force unionized workers to accept lower wages. If the union is asking for higher wages, or better benefits, an employer may use the threat of a lockout or an actual lockout to convince the union to back down.
== Lock-in ==
The term ''lock-in'' refers to the practice of physically preventing workers from leaving a workplace. In most jurisdictions this is illegal but is occasionally reported, especially in some developing countries. {{Citation needed|date=January 2008}}
More recently, lock-ins have been carried out by employees against management, which have been labelled '[[bossnapping]]' by the mainstream media. In France during March 2009, [[3M]]'s national manager was locked in his office for 24 hours by employees in a dispute over redundancies.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7964122.stm |title=Striking French workers free boss |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-03-26 |accessdate=2009-09-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article6031822.ece |title=Angry French workers turn to 'Bossnapping' to solve their problems |publisher= |date=2009-04-04 |accessdate=2009-09-19 | work=The Times | location=London | first=Adam | last=Sage}}{{Dead link|date=September 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Matlack |first=Carol |url=http://www.businessweek.com/globalbiz/blog/europeinsight/archives/2009/04/sarkozys_bossna.html |title=BusinessWeek Europe - Sarkozy's "Bossnapping" Dilemma |publisher=Businessweek.com |date= |accessdate=2009-09-19}}</ref> The following month, union employees of a call centre managed by [[Synovate]] in [[Auckland]] locked the front doors of the office, in response to management locking them out.<ref>{{cite news|author= |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10566554 |title=Locked out call-centre staff lock managers in |publisher=NZ Herald |date=2009-04-14 |accessdate=2009-09-19}}</ref> Such practices bear some resemblance to the ''[[gherao]]'' in India. It is also caused by disagreement between employer and employees in a certain department. ==Examples== === Ireland ===
The [[Dublin Lockout]] ({{lang-ga|FrithdhÃºnadh MÃ³r Bhaile-Ãtha-Cliath}}) was a major [[industrial dispute]] between approximately 20,000 workers and 300 employers which took place in [[Ireland]]'s capital city of [[Dublin]]. The dispute lasted from 26 August 1913 to 18 January 1914, and is often viewed as the most severe and significant industrial dispute in [[History of Ireland|Irish history]]. Central to the dispute was the workers' [[Labor rights|right to unionize]].
=== United States === In the [[United States]], under [[federal government of the United States|federal]] [[labor law]], an employer may hire only temporary replacements during a lockout. In a strike, unless it is an [[unfair labor practice]] (ULP) strike, an employer may legally hire permanent replacements. Also, in many U.S. states, employees who are locked out are eligible to receive [[unemployment benefits]], but are not eligible for such benefits during a strike.{{Citation needed|date=April 2008}}
For the above reasons, many American employers have historically been reluctant to impose lockouts, instead attempting to provoke a strike. However, as American unions have increasingly begun to resort to slowdowns rather than strikes, lockouts have come "back in fashion" for many employers. Even as incidents of strikes are on the decline, incidents of lockouts are on the rise in the U.S.{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}}
Recent notable lockout incidents have been reported in professional sports, notably involving the [[National Basketball Association]] in the [[1995 NBA lockout|1995 offseason]] and the [[1998â99 NBA lockout|1998â99]] and [[2011 NBA lockout|2011â12 seasons]], the [[National Hockey League]] in the [[1994â95 NHL lockout|1994â95]] and [[2004â05 NHL lockout|2004â05]] seasons, and the [[National Football League]] in the [[2011 NFL lockout|2011 offseason]]. In 2005, the NHL became the first major professional sports league in North America to cancel an entire season due to a lockout.
=== Australia === On 8 April 1998, major stevedoring company [[Patrick Corporation]] sought to restructure its operations for productivity reasons. In an [[1998 Australian waterfront dispute|industrial watershed event]], it sacked all its workers and imposed a lockout on wharves around Australia.<ref>[http://www.aph.gov.au/library/pubs/cib/1997-98/98cib15.htm Steve O'Neill, "Outline of the Waterfront Dispute", ''Current Issues Brief'', (Parliamentary Library), n15, 1998.]</ref>
On 29 October 2011, [[Qantas Airways]] declared a lockout of all domestic employees in the face of [[2011 Qantas trade union disputes|ongoing union industrial action]]. This cancelled all flights, grounding the entire fleet effective immediately.<ref>[http://au.news.yahoo.com/a/-/latest/11051127/qantas-grounds-entire-fleet/ Qantas grounds entire fleet] - ABC/Yahoo News, 29 Oct 2011</ref>
